title: Canada's Most Affordable City
subtitle: Real Affordability Index 2025
desc: What does it really cost to live in cities across Canada? The Real Affordability Index goes beyond average rent or income figures to reveal the actual monthly surplus or deficit faced by young people. This interactive chart highlights how income, expenses, and lived experiences intersect to shape financial stability‚Äîor strain‚Äîin each city. Use it to uncover the gaps between perception and reality in Canada‚Äôs affordability landscape.
profile_desc: Try changing the income and expenses using the profile to see how affordability shifts across gender, occupation, and life stages.
disclaimer_chart: * represents income based on a sample size under 50. ‚Ä† represents income based on provincial average. Data is derived from the Statistics Canada Labour Force Survey.
disclaimer_profile: Some options may be disabled due to low sample size.
disclaimer_gender:
*Our income data comes from Statistics Canada, which states the following regarding gender: 'Given that the non-binary population is small, data aggregation to a two-category gender variable is necessary to protect the confidentiality of responses provided. Individuals in the category ‚Äúnon-binary persons‚Äù are distributed into the other two gender categories.'

According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, 'nonbinary individuals assigned male at birth, transgender men, transgender women, and cisgender women all earn significantly less than comparable cisgender men.' As such, we have used the income of 'Women+' as a baseline for non-binary individuals. However, this may not fully reflect individual realities.

The NBER study found that 'nonbinary people assigned female at birth‚Äìdespite being more highly educated than other groups‚Äìearn significantly less than cisgender men, cisgender women, and all other gender minority groups. These gaps are larger at the bottom of the annual earnings distribution than at the top. [...] Lower-income transgender and nonbinary people may face something like a ‚Äústicky floor‚Äù (see Christofides et al. (2013)). Sticky floors represent a magnification of disadvantage for the most marginalized members of already disadvantaged groups. They may also be due to heterogeneity in the degree to which gender minority people are actually seen as cisgender people by the society surrounding them. If some members of gender minority groups are not perceived by others as gender minorities, we may expect those people to face smaller disparities.'
income_comparison: Overall, women{{age}} earn <1>{{percent}}%</1> {{direction}} than men{{occupation}}. The following chart shows the industries with the greatest gender-based income disparity.
1: Business, finance and admin occupations, except management
2: Natural and applied sciences occupations, except management
4: Education, law and social, community and government services occupations
5: Art, culture, recreation and sport occupations, except management
6: Sales and service occupations, except management
7: Trades, transport and equipment operators & related occupations
8: Natural resources, agriculture & related production occupations
9: Manufacturing and utilities occupations, except management
disclaimer_compare: *All subsequent profiles will be compared to this one
grocery_desc: Costs are in CAD. Prices reflect an average of non-discounted, in-stock items at common Canadian grocery stores. When available, the price represents the cost of goods prepared in Canada.
grocery_disclaimer: Note that the data is limited to what is available from major grocery store chains. There may be Canadian fruits and vegetables available that have not been marked as ‚ÄúPrepared in Canada‚Äù by the store.
grocery_more_desc: Interested in updated, historical, brand-specific, or api data access? Get in touch.
costs_more: It costs ${{cost}} more to buy Canadian!
rent_desc: Click on a city to start your housing journey.
rent_type_intro: So, you want to move out. What type of apartment are you looking for?
rent_area: Now, what area of the city are you looking for?
rent_cost: The current apartment would cost you...
rent_roommates: How many roommates do you want to split the cost with?
